C=E9dric,
 
Following up on what you said, I see "test" as a form of meta-d=
ata, but
since it is only there by convention the compiler can't help you i=
f you
spell "tset" instead. Annotations are native meta-data so the IDE can=
 help
more. OTOH, I can see how switching isn't trivial. After you've typed=
 "test"
the first thousand times, it becomes almost a reflex.
 
Regards,
 
=
Kent

When you write a test =
method that starts with "test", you are actually
tagging extra information =
to your method to indicate that it's a tag, but
you are doing it in a way t=
hat messes with your code.

You can't find a better use of annotations than=
 that...
